cards.front: Define the ideal diode using its v-i characteristic.
cards.back: Two modes: (1) reverse biased: v <= 0, i = 0 (open circuit), (2) forward conducting: v = 0, i >= 0 (short circuit). The characteristic is the negative v-axis joined to the positive i-axis.

cards.front: Write the ideal diode characteristic in set notation.
cards.back: R_ID = {(v, i) : v <= 0, i = 0} union {(v, i) : v = 0, i >= 0}. This is two rays meeting at the origin on the v-i plane.

cards.front: What does an ideal diode become in each of its two modes?
cards.back: Reverse biased: open circuit (i = 0, any v <= 0). Forward conducting: short circuit (v = 0, any i >= 0). It switches between the two extreme resistors.

cards.front: Describe the assume-and-check method for ideal diode circuits.
cards.back: Step 1: Assume each diode is conducting (short) or blocking (open). Step 2: Solve the linear circuit. Step 3: Check consistency (conducting: i >= 0; blocking: v <= 0). Step 4: If inconsistent, revise assumptions.

cards.front: When checking consistency for a diode assumed forward conducting, what must be true?
cards.back: The current through the diode must satisfy i >= 0. If i < 0, the assumption is wrong and you must try reverse biased instead.

cards.front: When checking consistency for a diode assumed reverse biased, what must be true?
cards.back: The voltage across the diode must satisfy v <= 0. If v > 0, the assumption is wrong and you must try forward conducting instead.

cards.front: How does the ideal diode differ from the A-Level silicon diode model?
cards.back: The ideal diode has zero forward voltage drop (no 0.7V turn-on voltage), an infinitely sharp transition, and zero reverse leakage current. It is a simpler model that captures only the switching behaviour.

cards.front: Is the ideal diode passive or active?
cards.back: Passive. In reverse bias, p = vi = v * 0 = 0. In forward conduction, p = vi = 0 * i = 0. Power is zero everywhere, so p >= 0 always.

cards.front: Name three applications where the ideal diode model is used.
cards.back: Half-wave and full-wave rectifiers, clipper circuits (limiting signal amplitude), and clamper circuits (shifting DC level). Also used in diode logic gates.

cards.front: With n ideal diodes in a circuit, what is the maximum number of state combinations to check?
cards.back: 2^n combinations (each diode is either conducting or blocking). In practice, physical reasoning eliminates most combinations quickly.
